info.tactics: Aces are highly-mobile duelists capable of skirmishing with single targets with high bursts of damage before retreating to recover their bombing bays and barrel roll reaction. They have relatively low health and will continually generate heat, requiring them to take off turns to recover their defensive layers.

Aegises are mobile defensive bunkers that fortify positions for their allies against incoming attacks. Notably, they are slow and their Defense Net system is symmetrical, so hostiles that successfully push onto their position may be able to turn this unit's defenses against them.

Archers excel at inflicting “choice punishment” on their enemies – they make characters choose between taking certain actions or letting the Archer attack them. Use Archers to lock down mobile or hard-hitting PCs or to cover for more vulnerable allies. Keep in mind that Archers are most effective when they can get fairly close to their targets, but they aren’t especially durable.

Assaults are simple, but effective strikers. While they operate consistently at moderate distance, they can represent a substantial threat if they close to melee and can Barrage. Hunker Down as defensive profile makes them especially resilient when they are entrenched and can sacrifice movement on their following turn without losing efficacy.

Barricades are one of the few enemies capable of easily reshaping the battlefield's terrain. Combined with their ability to slow maneuverable opponents, they can significantly gum up the playing field, making them particularly dangerous in movement-heavy sitreps.

Less of an offensive measure and more of a walking bulwark, Bastions serve as a mobile defensive measure that absorbs incoming munitions while discouraging enemies from pushing onto their position. Its offensive tools are limited, but they can harass enemies with a Rotary Grenade Launcher and Tech Actions if they are not dealt with.

Berserkers are supremely threatening in 1v1 melee encounters, as players will likely struggle to strip their primary defensive layer and fend them off with limited activations. Their high mobility makes them a constant threat as they can push aggressively onto vulnerable targets and provide an extremely thorny situation to get out of.

Bombards are long-range artillery pieces with extremely limited mobility. They aim to pressure characters off of points or to deny routes of ingress by laying down large blasts that continue to deal damage to characters that move into them or end their turn there. With the additional damage from Active Bombardment, players will be punished heavily for remaining in one place for too long.

Cataphracts are highly mobile duelists that leverage positioning to isolate vulnerable enemies and force them into difficult situations. Their defensive layer is ideal against a single target, so they are pressured to keep their distance from clusters of hostiles.
Demolishers are a niche class that presents a very slow threat for players to work around, but is capable of a burst of speed with Breach Ram that can reshape the battlefield substantially.

Engineers are snowballing characters that reinforced positions with autonomous turrets that attack the nearest enemy and can overwatch enemies that get too close. They lack their own ranged options, so are highly reliant on their turrets and allies to give them the space to operate without being harrassed.

Hives are zone-based controllers that alternate between placing Razor Swarms and defensively positioning with Shadow Swarms. They have a weapon that can punish players that have many conditions, making Drone Barrage a potentially very significant punish if characters are committed to staying in one spot.

Hornets are small, fast, and fragile controllers that are excellent for harassing strikers that primarily target Evasion. Their low E-Defence and HP make them very vulnerable to Smart and Reliable weapons, as well as player control options.

Lurkers are a creeping striker that crawls across the field, creating Shroud Zones that act as their primary defensive layer. They are very dangerous if they manage to engage a player while within a Shroud Zone, but they lack mobility and favor entrenching in a general location and lashing out at enemies that get too close.

Enshrouded are units that focus on entrenching in a specific spot and threating a significant area around them. Their weapon cannot be used unless this character Immobilizes itself, so it is most effective at defending a position or denying a point of ingress.

Mirages are support characters that are capable of shuffling their allies around the field, frustrating positioning efforts of players. Their Warp Sensors action can further mitigate incoming damage, but Mirage lacks any weaponry and cannot operate well outside of their specific niche.

Priests are all-in support mechs that seek to partner with more dangerous foes, empowering them with Investiture. Doing so significantly reduces their positional flexibility, but can make for incredibly dangerous foes, particularly when paired with the priest's other tools for mitigating incoming damage.

Pyros are slow, tough, and threatening defenders that interfere with ranged attacks with their Firebreak Shield once they entrench in a position. They are quite threatening up close, so they serve largely as a deterrent to ingress on their position, although they lack tools that interefere with player movement and are quite susceptible to player abilities that upset their positioning.

Rainmakers are more precise area-denial artillery pieces than Bombards, featuring the ability to mark spaces that punish characters for moving into them or remaining close enough to be knocked back into them on their following turn. Their limited speed and defensive options make them vulnerable to counter-artillery and aggressive enemy strikers.

Ronins are strikers that excel at dueling artillery, shrugging off the hardest hitting attacks with Rebound while they advance on vulnerable targets. They are heavily reliant on this defensive trait, so appropriate team coordination may be required to hit them while there guard is down, or disable their reactions entirely.

Scourers deal a great deal of damage when they focus on single targets, attacking them multiple times. They can be used to crack tough or slow moving opponents very easily. However, they are much less effective when forced to switch targets, and need to stay still to make the most of their weapons.

Scouts are support mechs designed to increase the damage dealt by their allies. They deal no damage themselves, but Marker Rifle and Cloaking Field allow them to both keep allied characters alive and prevent enemies from hiding. They are most effective when serving as a stationary spotter next to an artillery unit, but they are mobile enough to provide support in even the most frenetic skirmishes.

Seeders specialize in area denial, controlling enemy movement with their mines. Since Seeders can place a mine each turn, they can quickly turn part of the battlefield into a mess when left to their own devices. Allied characters can trigger the Seeder's mines, so they will generally use them to create space between vulnerable allies and aggressive enemies.

Sentinels are fast defenders that focus on protecting their allies with Overwatch and the In Your Face trait. They are fairly short-range attackers, relying on positioning to get the most from their kit, and aren’t as resilient as other defenders, but are capable of repositioning if characters attempt to push past them after their Overwatch is expended.

Rightly feared, Snipers are devastating when it comes to dealing focused damage. Using Sniper’s Mark, they can deal direct structure damage, making short work of almost any character. Opponents can avoid this with clever use of cover, or by dropping Prone. Snipers’ main downside is that they need to be fairly stationary to do their best work, as their rifle requires a full action to fire, and they are not allowed to reposition before taking their shot on their turn.

Specters are mobile strikers that shine against foes that make the mistake of being caught alone. Their survivability is very contingent on them remaining Invisible and Hidden, so they will do their best to stay clear of any allies that may disrupt their Tactical Cloak, and will need to choose their targets carefully to benefit from their Hunt trait.

info.flavor: Support-archetype mechs keep their allies alive and operational with a broad library of immediate triage systems, from basic flash-weld plating through to shallow–medium structural reinforcement packs and whitewash nanite slurry. From the famed Laughter of a Solemn God, working the front lines of Boundary Garden’s battlefields, to the precision actions undertaken by the rogue-world hunters of ExtraSolar Acquisitions, Inc., the efficacy of Support-archetype mechs is unparalleled when mech teams need to stay alive longer than deployment.
info.tactics: Supports are bulky mechs that can’t deal any damage but have access to powerful healing and condition-clearing effects. Despite their resilience, they have no way to defend themselves and need to get close to their allies in order to be effective. Savvy players will shoot and destroy their Restock Drones before they are activated, denying an opportunity for healing.

Stormwings are quick, evasive skirmishers that dip in and out of the fray to pick apart softer targets. Their weapons struggle against armored targets, so they are most efficient when targeting characters that rely on evasion or positioning as their primary defensive tools.

Striders are versatile, mode-swapping units that attempt to dance between two or more roles. When building Striders, you may wish to remove one or more of its base kits in favor of optional ones to cut back on the number of options available while running combats; each kit comes with a kit swap bonus and all options that have that kit name listed (e.g. Marksman, Skirmisher, etc.).

Witches are heat-based strikers that pressure players to carefully mind their heat caps while it is on the field. While relatively fragile for a striker, they are fast and benefit from Invisibility on their turn, allowing them to slip in and threaten to expose players who tread too close to their heatcap, as they can deal a staggering burst of heat if they get into melee and can trigger their Overwatch with Fugue State on the same turn.

Hags are unorthodox controllers that utilize an array of peculiar tools to frustrate their enemies' turns, from ruining line of sight, to discharging loading weapons, to forcing players to choose between movement and attacking.

info.flavor:
All kinds of people end up on the battlefield, including pilots, VIPs, and bystanders.
You will mostly use Human NPCs when someone climbs out of their mech mid-battle; if you want a proper group of infantry, use the Squad class instead. Humans can never take other templates, and cannot gain structure.

Although individual pilots and other non-mechanized soldiers might not present much of a threat to most mechs, a squad of infantry with the right gear and training can be dangerous in their own right.
Squads are exactly what they sound like: small groups of five to ten armed and armored soldiers represented as one character on the battlefield.

Monstrosities are especially large or horrifying natural predators. Although they are usually wild, some monstrosities can be domesticated and trained for combat: such creatures are in high demand along the furthest reaches of the galaxy.
